questions.text: A 16 year old boy presented with dish shaped deformity of the anterior portion of the ribs. Identify the false statement from below regarding the diagnosis:

options.label: B
options.text: Ravitch or Nuss procedure is used to treat it

options.label: C
options.text: Sternum is elevated above the level of the ribs in Pectus carinatum

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery is best left until the late teen

questions.correct_answer: A. Pectus excavatum causes respiratory problems
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pectus excavatum causes respiratory problems Pectus excavatum: The sternum is depressed, with a dish-shaped deformity of the anterior portions of the ribs on one or both sides. It is never a cause of respiratory problems. It can be repaired to improve its cosmetic appearance either as an open procedure (the Ravitch procedure) which involves resecting the affected costal cartilages and mobilizing the sternum, or as a minimally invasive technique, the Nuss procedure. A metal bar is placed behind the sternum to hold this central panel in its new position and has to be removed after a period of time. Pectus carinatum (pigeon chest): In this condition the sternum is elevated above the level of the ribs and treatment is offered for cosmetic reasons. The sternum is mobilized and allowed to fall back into place. It often comes to light during the growth spurt at adolescence when, of course, the teenager is particularly sensitive about appearance. Most patients are asymptomatic and the only justification for treatment is on cosmetic grounds. Some surgeons make a very good case for this but the risk of morbidity and of a less than perfect result must be clearly spelt out to the patient and his/her parents. Surgery involves mobilizing the sternum with the costal cartilages so that the sternum can be flattened to a more anatomical position. Surgery is best left until the late teens, when further growth of the chest wall is unlikely.

questions.text: How many lymph node zones and stations respectively are there related to the bronchial tree?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

7,14 There are 7 lymph node zones and 14 lymph node stations related to the bronchial tree.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adynamic lung investigation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arterial Blood Gas Dynamic lung investigations are those which measure the lung volumes as well as the ability of the lungs to exchange gasses across the alveolar membrane efficiently. These include PEFR, FEV1, FVC, DLCO, SpO2, ABG They are used to determine the functional capacity of the lungs, predict the severity of the disease and the response to treatment.

Highyeild:

TABLE 60.2 Arterial blood gases: 'normal values'. pH 7.35-7.45 PaCO2 4.5-6 kPa (35-50 mmHg) PaO2 11-14 kPa (83-105 mmHg) Standard bicarbonate 22-28 mmol/L Anion gap 10-16 mmol/L Chloride 98-107 mmol/L

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Video Assisted Thoracoscopy is a minimally invasive investigation and is an adynamic investigation of the lung Option: B. Endobronchial ultrasound is an adynamic investigation as it does not measure the lung volumes or gaseous exchange across the alveoli Option: D. Sputum cytology is also an adynamic investigation of the lung.

Extraedge:

Various functional assessments can help predict surgical outcome after lung resection Assessments include shuttle walk test, 6-minute walk test, stair climbing, oxygen saturations, and cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) These assessments are recommended for patients at moderate or high risk of postoperative dyspnoea Shuttle walk test distance of >400 m and CPET of >15 mL/kg/min are cut-off values for good function in patients with moderate to high risk of postoperative dyspnoea.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct statement about DLCO?

options.label: A
options.text: Depends on the integrity of lungs’ alveolar capillary surface area for gas exchange

options.label: B
options.text: Most important determinant of fitness for lung surgery

options.label: D
options.text: DLCO and FVC are the two most important parameters for predicting post-operative dyspnoea in patients undergoing lung surgery

questions.correct_answer: D. DLCO and FVC are the two most important parameters for predicting post-operative dyspnoea in patients undergoing lung surgery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

DLCO and FVC are the two most important parameters for predicting post-operative dyspnoea in patients undergoing lung surgery Diffusion capacity and FEV1 are the two most important parameters for predicting post-operative dyspnoea in patients undergoing lung surgery.

Highyeild:

Forced vital capacity (FVC) measures air displaced from maximal inspiration to maximal expiration. FVC and FEV1 can be measured with a Vitalograph and a ratio (FEV1/FVC) can be calculated. The FEV1 and DLCO tests are used to predict the risk of postoperative dyspnoea after lung resection. Predicted postoperative values can be calculated by considering the volume of lung expected to be removed at surgery. An optimal cutoff of postoperative predicted FEV1 of 40% is often cited, but there is limited data to provide guidance on this figure. Patients should still be offered surgical resection if the predicted risk of postoperative dyspnoea is moderate or high, as long as they understand and accept the associated risks and complications.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The diffusion capacity , also known as the transfer factor , depends on the patient’s current hemoglobin level and the integrity of the lung’s alveolar-capillary surface area for gas exchange . Option: C. It cannot be performed at the bedside as it needs proper equipment and setup. Option: B. It is the most important determinant of fitness for lung surgery , especially resections of part of the lung.

Extraedge:

Various functional assessments can help predict surgical outcome after lung resection Assessments include shuttle walk test, 6-minute walk test, stair climbing, oxygen saturations, and cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) These assessments are recommended for patients at moderate or high risk of postoperative dyspnoea Shuttle walk test distance of >400 m and CPET of >15 mL/kg/min are cut-off values for good function in patients with moderate to high risk of postoperative dyspnoea.

questions.text: Which of the following is not representative of an obstructive pathology in the lung?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

FEV1/FVC > 80 FEV1/FVC is <70 in obstructive lung disease and >80 in restrictive lung disease

Highyeild:

Forced vital capacity (FVC) measures air displaced from maximal inspiration to maximal expiration. FVC and FEV1 can be measured with a Vitalograph and a ratio (FEV1/FVC) can be calculated. A low ratio indicates obstruction and the test should be repeated after bronchodilators. A normal ratio indicates a restrictive pathology. There are two categories of lung disease: obstructive and restrictive. Obstructive conditions, like asthma or emphysema, impair air flow in and out of the lungs. Restrictive disease, like lung fibrosis, causes the lungs to lose size or elasticity. Figure 60.5 Spirometry. (a) Spirogram tracings obtained from a Vitalograph: (i) normal forced expiratory volume in 1 s (FEV.) 3.1 litres, forced vital capacity (FVC) 3.8 litres, FEV,/FVC 82%; (ii) obstructive defect, reversible asthma, p before a bronchodilator, FEV, 1.4 litres, FVC 3.5 litres, FEV₁/FVC 40%; qafter a bronchodilator, FEV, 2.5 litres, FVC 3.5 litres, FEV./FVC71%; (iii) restrictive defect, fibrosing alveolitis, FEV, 1.8 litres, FVC 2.0 litres, FEV,/FVC 90%. No change with bronchodilators. (b) Changes in lung volume in obstructive and restrictive lung disease. (Reproduced from Gray HH. Pulmonary embolism. Medicine International 1993; 21: 477, by kind permission of the Medicine Group (Journals) Ltd.)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. PEFR is decreased in obstructive lung disease and can be decreased or normal in restrictive lung disease. TABLE 55.1 Spirometry values in obstructive and restrictive lung diseases. Obstructive pattern Restrictive pattern PEFR ↓↓ Normal or↓ FEV₁ ↓↓ Normal or↓ FVC Normal or↓ ↓↓ FEV1/FVC <70 >80 Option: B. FEV1 is decreased in obstructive lung disease and can be decreased or Normal in restrictive lung disease. Option: C. FVC is decreased in restrictive lung disease and can be decreased or Normal in obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: A 70 year old male patient presents to you with complaints of cough since the past 3 months and an episode of haemoptysis 2 days back. He also complains of weight loss and decreased appetite. He is a known smoker with a history of 30 pack years. What is your next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chest X-ray A 70- year- old male smoker with complaints of cough, haemoptysis and weight loss point towards a possible diagnosis of lung malignancy. The first step in cases of suspected lung malignancy is a chest X-ray.

Highyeild:

Chest X-ray is effective in detecting most lung cancers However, some early-stage tumors that can be treated may be hidden by surrounding structures on the X-ray Secondary effects like pleural effusion, distal collapse, and elevated hemidiaphragm may be visible on the X-ray

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option D - If there is a lesion seen on chest X-ray, chest CT is the next investigation. Option B - ATT is not the correct answer as the suspected diagnosis in this case is not tuberculosis. Option C - Mantoux test or the tuberculin skin test is also not the correct answer as tuberculosis is not the suspected diagnosis in this case

Extraedge:

Serial chest X-rays may be used to monitor the growth or regression of lung tumors over time. However, for a more detailed and accurate evaluation of suspected lung cancer, a CT scan of the chest is usually recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding lung investigations is/are true? Investigation of choice for mediastinal pathology is endoscopic ultrasound Most sensitive investigation for detecting mediastinal lymphadenopathy is VATS Best investigation for diagnosis of mediastinal pathology is mediastinoscopy Sputum cytology has a high false positive rate Investigation of choice for staging lung malignancy is PET-CT Select the correct answer from the given below code:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,3,5

Highyeild:

Mediastinoscopy, mediastinotomy, VATS or thoracotomy are procedures used to establish tissue diagnosis and staging for lymph node/lung biopsy. Staging helps determine resectability, and histological proof of the status of mediastinal nodes is important to avoid unnecessary thoracotomy for incurable cancers or to avoid denying surgery to patients with benign enlarged lymph nodes. Mediastinoscopy involves an incision in the neck, blunt dissection in front of the trachea, and access to paratracheal and subcarinal nodes for biopsies. Statement 1 - Investigation of choice for mediastinal pathology and lymphadenopathy is endoscopic ultrasound Statement 2 - It is also the most sensitive investigation for detecting mediastinal lymphadenopathy as it can detect lymph nodes as small as 3 mm Statement 3 - Best investigation for mediastinal pathology is mediastinoscopy or video assisted thoracoscopy guided biopsy Statement 4 - Sputum cytology has a high false negative rate Statement 5 - Investigation of choice for staging lung malignancy is PET-CT

Extraedge:

These techniques can also be used to diagnose other mediastinal conditions such as lymphoma, anterior mediastinal tumors, thymoma, sarcoid, tuberculosis, or any other cause of lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 75- year- old male patient with symptoms suggestive of carcinoma lung undergoes a chest X-ray. The chest X-ray reveals a lesion at the base of the right lung. This is followed by a CT scan of the chest which reveals a peripheral basal solid lesion with features worrisome for a malignancy. What is the next step in diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT guided FNA When a peripheral lesion is seen on CT chest, the next investigation is CT guided fine needle aspiration cytology.

Highyeild:

Percutaneous CT-guided FNA (fine needle aspiration) and core biopsy are effective methods for obtaining tissue samples for cytological and histological examination in the diagnosis of larger and peripheral lung lesions. Pneumothorax is a common complication but is typically not severe enough to require chest tube drainage

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. In case of a central lesion we prefer flexible bronchoscopy guided biopsy Option: B. PET-CT is done for staging of lung cancer once the diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy/FNA. Option: D. If the results are inconclusive, then a VATS guided biopsy is done

Extraedge:

Patients with poor respiratory reserve may not be suitable for the procedure due to the potential risk of even a small pneumothorax.

questions.text: Consider the following statements with respect to uses of bronchoscopy: Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred for diagnosis of carcinoma bronchus Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred for stent placement Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred for endobronchial resections Flexible bronchoscopy is preferred for foreign body removal Flexible bronchoscopy is preferred for diagnosis of inflammatory pathologies Mark the correct option with respect to true/false:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-F, 2-T, 3-T, 4-F, 5-T Flexible bronchoscopy is preferred for its diagnostic value as it is used for confirmation of lung pathologies, diagnosis of carcinoma bronchus and inflammatory/infective pathologies of the lung. Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred for its therapeutic value in removal of of secretions/foreign bodies, stent placement and endobronchial resections Option 1 – Flexible bronchoscopy is preferred for diagnosis of carcinoma bronchus Option 2 – Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred for stent placement. Option 3 – Rigid bronchoscopy is also preferred for Endobronchial resection of tumors/masses Option 4 – For foreign body removal also, we prefer rigid bronchoscopy Option 5 – For diagnostic purposes, flexible bronchoscopy is preferred over rigid bronchoscopy.

Highyeild:

Flexible bronchoscopy is often done with sedation, especially for patients with centrally located lung cancers. It enables evaluation of the segmental airway and allows for cytological testing through brushing and washing of the affected segmental bronchi. Transbronchial needle aspiration (TBNA) can also be performed during flexible bronchoscopy. General anesthesia is typically needed for rigid bronchoscopy. It's best suited for therapeutic procedures like removing foreign objects or performing surgery within the airway. The bronchoscope is inserted directly into the trachea through the oropharynx under direct visualization

questions.text: A 45 year old female planned for cholecystectomy underwent pre-operative assessment during which a chest X-ray was done which revealed a coin shaped opacity in the right lung. She did not have any symptoms other than episodic abdominal pain from cholelithiasis? What is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Ask for a previous chest X-ray

questions.correct_answer: C. Ask for a previous chest X-ray
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ask for a previous chest X-ray The coin shaped opacity in the right lung on chest X-ray is an incidental finding. The next best step would be to look for the presence of a similar lesion on a previous X-ray, the presence of which would rule out a malignancy and save the patient from the trouble of undergoing a battery of tests.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B - If the mass is found to be new in origin or no previous chest X-ray is available, CT chest is the next best step. Option D – If the mass is found to be suspicious for a malignant etiology, bronchoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice. Option A - Repeating chest X-ray in 2 weeks may not be of any significant diagnostic value. Bronchoscopy with biopsy is not the immediate next step as explained above.

questions.text: Which of the following is generally preferred to surgically approach the lung in case of trauma to the chest?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterolateral thoracotomy Option: A, B. In general , Anterolateral thoracotomy is preferred to approach the lung in cases of trauma while posterolateral thoracotomy is generally preferred in other lesions of thorax Option: C. VATS is the surgical approach of choice in cases of lung pathologies Option: D. Mediastinotomy is preferred to gain access to mediastinal lymph nodes as well as to lung tumors infiltrating into the mediastinum.

Highyeild:

Immediate thoracotomy is necessary in the emergency department for controlling hemorrhage, cardiac tamponade, or internal cardiac massage. Emergency sternotomy is required for anterior mediastinal structures and the heart. Left anterolateral thoracotomy is necessary if the patient is in extremis with a falling systolic blood pressure.

Extraedge:

Performing a thoracotomy in the operating theater is better than attempting emergency surgery in the resuscitation area. Resuscitation room thoracotomy following blunt trauma has limited indications and is rarely successful.
